metadata.title: Bearing Load Calculation and Stress-Strain Curves
metadata.subject: Mechanics of Materials

content.description: A stress-strain curve with stress ($\sigma$) on the y-axis and strain ($\epsilon$) on the x-axis. It depicts the behavior of two types of materials: brittle and ductile. The brittle material curve (labeled 'brittle material') shows a linear elastic region up to an ultimate tensile strength ($\sigma_{\text{ultimate}}$) and then fractures. The ductile material curve (labeled 'Ductile material') shows an initial linear elastic region up to a proportional limit (PL), followed by a yield point with upper ($\sigma_{\text{uy}}$) and lower ($\sigma_{\text{ly}}$) yield stresses, a region of strain hardening up to an ultimate stress ($\sigma_{\text{ultimate}}$), and finally a decrease in stress before fracture ($\sigma_{\text{f}}$). The point $E \cdot \epsilon_y$ is also marked, likely indicating the elastic limit.
